description: From Middle English rengen, from Old French rengier (“to range, to rank, to order,”), from the noun renc, reng, ranc, rang (“a rank, row”), from Frankish *hring, from Proto-Germanic *hringaz (“ring, circle, curve”).

entries.meaning: A line or series of mountains, buildings, etc.
A fireplace; a fire or other cooking apparatus; now specifically, a large cooking stove with many hotplates.
Selection, array.
examples: We sell a wide range of cars.

entries.meaning: An area for practicing shooting at targets.
An area for military training or equipment testing.
examples: Synonyms: base, training area, training ground

entries.meaning: The distance from a person or sensor to an object, target, emanation, or event.
examples: We could see the ship at a range of five miles.
One can use the speed of sound to estimate the range of a lightning flash.
Synonyms: distance, radius

entries.meaning: The maximum distance or reach of capability (of a weapon, radio, detector, etc.).
examples: This missile's range is 500 kilometres.

entries.meaning: The distance a vehicle (e.g., a car, bicycle, lorry, or aircraft) can travel without refueling.
examples: This aircraft's range is 15 000 kilometres.

entries.meaning: An area of open, often unfenced, grazing land.
The extent or space taken in by anything excursive; compass or extent of excursion; reach; scope.
(mathematics) The set of values (points) which a function can obtain.
examples: Antonym: domain

entries.meaning: (statistics) The length of the smallest interval which contains all the data in a sample; the difference between the largest and smallest observations in the sample.
(sports, baseball) The defensive area that a player can cover.
examples: Jones has good range for a big man.

entries.meaning: (music) The scale of all the tones a voice or an instrument can produce.
examples: Synonym: compass

entries.meaning: (ecology) The geographical area or zone where a species is normally naturally found.
(programming) A sequential list of values specified by an iterator.
examples: std::for_each  calls the given function on each value in the input range.

entries.meaning: An aggregate of individuals in one rank or degree; an order; a class.
(obsolete) The step of a ladder; a rung.
(obsolete, UK, dialect) A bolting sieve to sift meal.
A wandering or roving; a going to and fro; an excursion; a ramble; an expedition.
examples: He may take a range all the world over.

entries.meaning: (US, historical) In the public land system, a row or line of townships lying between two succession meridian lines six miles apart.
The variety of roles that an actor can play in a satisfactory way.
examples: By playing in comedies as well as in dramas he has proved his range as an actor.
By playing in comedies as well as in dramas he has proved his acting range.

verbs.description: range (third-person singular simple present ranges, present participle ranging, simple past and past participle ranged) For more quotations using this term, see Citations:range.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To travel over (an area, etc); to roam, wander. [from 15th c.]
(transitive) To rove over or through.
examples: to range the fields

entries.meaning: (obsolete, intransitive) To exercise the power of something over something else; to cause to submit to, over. [16th–19th c.]
(transitive) To bring (something) into a specified position or relationship (especially, of opposition) with something else. [from 16th c.]
(intransitive) Of a variable, to be able to take any of the values in a specified range.
examples: The variable x ranges over all real values from 0 to 10.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To classify.
examples: to range plants and animals in genera and species

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To form a line or a row.
examples: The front of a house ranges with the street.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be placed in order; to be ranked; to admit of arrangement or classification; to rank.
(transitive) To set in a row, or in rows; to place in a regular line or lines, or in ranks; to dispose in the proper order.
examples: Maccabeus ranged his army by hands.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To place among others in a line, row, or order, as in the ranks of an army; usually, reflexively and figuratively, to espouse a cause, to join a party, etc.
examples: It would be absurd in me to range myself on the side of the Duke of Bedford and the corresponding society.

entries.meaning: (biology) To be native to, or live in, a certain district or region.
examples: The peba ranges from Texas to Paraguay.

entries.meaning: (military, of artillery) To determine the range to a target.
To sail or pass in a direction parallel to or near.
examples: to range the coast

entries.meaning: (baseball) Of a player, to travel a significant distance for a defensive play.
